deployedGeneratedSources.name: #utility.yul

documentation.text:
A metaverse hub can receive "plugs" (extensions) in the form of
 different contracts (implementing IMetaversePlugin). This
 plug mechanism allows extending the metaverse with new asset
 types and new asset instances (each plug-in is managed by the
 team, not publicly added by external users).
 Each of those contracts will make use of their own logic while
 interacting with the metaverse, which involves having full access
 to the whole metaverse assets (e.g. taking assets from the users
 or granting assets to the users).

This is the list of plug-ins that are being added to the hub.
 Each contract has its separate logic but they have access to
 the same set of features. Once a contract is added, it will
 never be removed from this list. This mapping tells whether
 a contract in particular has permission(s) to define a type
 and mint tokens for an address.
This is the enumerable list of plug-ins added to this hub.
The linked brand registry for this metaverse.
The linked economy for this metaverse.

Types are identified as integer values, and each registered type
 will have a non-zero responsible address (serving to metadata
 resolution and also to account for the existence of a given type).
 The type 1 (0x1) will be the first type, and actually it will be
 the brand type. Other NFT types will be registered using indices
 lower to (1<<255), while FT types will be registered using indices
 greater than or equal to that value (i.e. starting with binary {1}).
 In the case of the FTs, the index in this mapping is also their
 token id. This is not the same for NFTs (they have one extra level
 of indirection since multiple ids might share the same type). A
 special type id will be regarded as invalid type (i.e. it will
 not count as NFT nor FT type, but as a non-existent type): 0 (0x0).
 The responsible serves two purposes: The first one, is to resolve
 the metadata of a given token id (be it FT or NFT). The second one
 is to account for one of such tokens being burned. The responsible
 will actually be one of the registered plug-ins, on each case (save
 for the brands case, which is resolved by this contract, and the
 invalid case, which has no resolver).

Now, each NFT id will be registered here along its token type. The
 difference with the fungible tokens (they're already registered in
 the `tokenTypes` mapping) is that they need to be registered with
 a particular token type. Also, both the NFT id and its associated
 token type will be lower than (1<<255) since, otherwise, they would
 be using values corresponding to the FT side (both for IDs and type
 indices). Brand NFTs are not included in this mapping (they are only
 characterized by being < (1 << 160)).

Holds the next FT index to try, in the next iteration, for respective
 brand(s) requesting one. These ids are, at most, 1<<64 - 1.

Holds the next NFT type to try, in the next iteration. The initial
 value to try is 2 (0 means "invalid" and 1 means "brand").

Holds the next NFT index to try, in the next iteration. The initial
 value to try is 1 above the maximum value brand addresses can take.

Permission: Superuser (all the permissions are considered given to
 a superuser which is registered in the metaverse). The only thing
 that superuser per-se cannot do is to add more superusers.
Permission: To add a plug-in.
Permission: To set a brand registry.
Permission: To set the related economy.
Maintains the permissions assigned to this metaverse.

documentation.text:
Defines the resolution of a fungible token type. The token id must be
 in the range of the fungible token ids.

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: cannot define more NFT types"

documentation.text:
Defines the resolution of a non-fungible token type. The token id must
 be in the range of the fungible token (type) ids (strictly > 0, strictly
 < (1 << 255)).
Mints a specific fungible token type, in a certain amount.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted"

arguments.value: Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted"

documentation.text:
Mints a specific non-fungible token type, using a specific type (and always using
 an amount of 1). It is an error if the chosen type is unknown or < 2, since those
 types are reserved for being invalid or brands. Also, it is an error if the chosen
 type is not for that plug-in.

Burns any FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the token being burned.

Burns many FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the token being burned.

Burns any NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the tokens being burned.

Burns many NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the tokens being burned.

documentation.text: Mints a specific brand token for a given user. The brand is stated as its address.

Retrieves the metadata uri from the appropriate plug-in, if any. If the type id is
 not registered then return an empty string.

Retrieves the metadata uri of a given token. WARNING: This method
 will consume a lot of gas if invoked inside a transaction, so
 it is recommended to invoke this method in the context of a
 CALL, and never in the context of a SEND (even as part of other
 contract's code).
Hook to be invoked as part of a transfer from ERC1155.

Tells whether an address is a valid metaverse plug-in contract for
 this metaverse in particular.

Restricts an action to senders that are considered to have
 certain permission in the metaverse.

Tells whether a user has a specific permission on the metaverse, or
 is its owner.

This event is triggered when a permission is set or revoked
 for a given user in the whole metaverse.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: cannot grant a permission to address 0"

arguments.value: Metaverse: cannot grant a permission to address 0

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: cannot grant a permission to address 0"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: SUPERUSER permission cannot be added by this user"

arguments.value: Metaverse: SUPERUSER permission cannot be added by this user

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: SUPERUSER permission cannot be added by this user"

documentation.text:
Grants a permission to a user. This action is reserved to owners,
 approved operators, or allowed superusers. However, superuser cannot
 set, in particular, the SUPERUSER permission itself.

A metaverse hub can receive "plugs" (extensions) in the form of
 different contracts (implementing IMetaversePlugin). This
 plug mechanism allows extending the metaverse with new asset
 types and new asset instances (each plug-in is managed by the
 team, not publicly added by external users).
 Each of those contracts will make use of their own logic while
 interacting with the metaverse, which involves having full access
 to the whole metaverse assets (e.g. taking assets from the users
 or granting assets to the users).

This is the list of plug-ins that are being added to the hub.
 Each contract has its separate logic but they have access to
 the same set of features. Once a contract is added, it will
 never be removed from this list. This mapping tells whether
 a contract in particular has permission(s) to define a type
 and mint tokens for an address.
This is the enumerable list of plug-ins added to this hub.
The linked brand registry for this metaverse.
The linked economy for this metaverse.

Types are identified as integer values, and each registered type
 will have a non-zero responsible address (serving to metadata
 resolution and also to account for the existence of a given type).
 The type 1 (0x1) will be the first type, and actually it will be
 the brand type. Other NFT types will be registered using indices
 lower to (1<<255), while FT types will be registered using indices
 greater than or equal to that value (i.e. starting with binary {1}).
 In the case of the FTs, the index in this mapping is also their
 token id. This is not the same for NFTs (they have one extra level
 of indirection since multiple ids might share the same type). A
 special type id will be regarded as invalid type (i.e. it will
 not count as NFT nor FT type, but as a non-existent type): 0 (0x0).
 The responsible serves two purposes: The first one, is to resolve
 the metadata of a given token id (be it FT or NFT). The second one
 is to account for one of such tokens being burned. The responsible
 will actually be one of the registered plug-ins, on each case (save
 for the brands case, which is resolved by this contract, and the
 invalid case, which has no resolver).

Now, each NFT id will be registered here along its token type. The
 difference with the fungible tokens (they're already registered in
 the `tokenTypes` mapping) is that they need to be registered with
 a particular token type. Also, both the NFT id and its associated
 token type will be lower than (1<<255) since, otherwise, they would
 be using values corresponding to the FT side (both for IDs and type
 indices). Brand NFTs are not included in this mapping (they are only
 characterized by being < (1 << 160)).

Holds the next FT index to try, in the next iteration, for respective
 brand(s) requesting one. These ids are, at most, 1<<64 - 1.

Holds the next NFT type to try, in the next iteration. The initial
 value to try is 2 (0 means "invalid" and 1 means "brand").

Holds the next NFT index to try, in the next iteration. The initial
 value to try is 1 above the maximum value brand addresses can take.

Permission: Superuser (all the permissions are considered given to
 a superuser which is registered in the metaverse). The only thing
 that superuser per-se cannot do is to add more superusers.
Permission: To add a plug-in.
Permission: To set a brand registry.
Permission: To set the related economy.
Maintains the permissions assigned to this metaverse.

documentation.text:
Defines the resolution of a non-fungible token type. The token id must
 be in the range of the fungible token (type) ids (strictly > 0, strictly
 < (1 << 255)).
Mints a specific fungible token type, in a certain amount.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted"

arguments.value: Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Metaverse: NFT types 0 (invalid) and 1 (brand) cannot be minted"

documentation.text:
Mints a specific non-fungible token type, using a specific type (and always using
 an amount of 1). It is an error if the chosen type is unknown or < 2, since those
 types are reserved for being invalid or brands. Also, it is an error if the chosen
 type is not for that plug-in.

Burns any FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the token being burned.

Burns many FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the token being burned.

Burns any NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the tokens being burned.

Burns many NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines
 the type of the tokens being burned.

documentation.text: Mints a specific brand token for a given user. The brand is stated as its address.

Retrieves the metadata uri from the appropriate plug-in, if any. If the type id is
 not registered then return an empty string.

Retrieves the metadata uri of a given token. WARNING: This method
 will consume a lot of gas if invoked inside a transaction, so
 it is recommended to invoke this method in the context of a
 CALL, and never in the context of a SEND (even as part of other
 contract's code).
Hook to be invoked as part of a transfer from ERC1155.

 certain permission in the metaverse.

Tells whether a user has a specific permission on the metaverse, or

This event is triggered when a permission is set or revoked
 for a given user in the whole metaverse.

documentation.text:
Grants a permission to a user. This action is reserved to owners,
 approved operators, or allowed superusers. However, superuser cannot
 set, in particular, the SUPERUSER permission itself.

owner().details: Returns the address of the current owner.

renounceOwnership().details: Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call `onlyOwner` functions anymore. Can only be called by the current owner. NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner, thereby removing any functionality that is only available to the owner.

transferOwnership(address).details: Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`). Can only be called by the current owner.

PermissionChanged(bytes32,address,bool).notice: This event is triggered when a permission is set or revoked for a given user in the whole metaverse.

addPlugin(address).notice: Adds a plug-in contract to this metaverse.

brandRegistry().notice: The linked brand registry for this metaverse.

burnFT(uint256,uint256).notice: Burns any FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines the type of the token being burned.

burnFTs(uint256[],uint256[]).notice: Burns many FT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines the type of the token being burned.

burnNFT(uint256).notice: Burns any NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines the type of the tokens being burned.

burnNFTs(uint256[]).notice: Burns many NFT the sender has, provided the sender is a plugin and also defines the type of the tokens being burned.

defineNextFTType(address).notice: Defines the resolution of a fungible token type. The token id must be in the range of the fungible token ids.

defineNextNFTType().notice: Defines the resolution of a non-fungible token type. The token id must be in the range of the fungible token (type) ids (strictly > 0, strictly < (1 << 255)).

economy().notice: The linked economy for this metaverse.

isAllowed(bytes32,address).notice: Tells whether a user has a specific permission on the metaverse, or is its owner.

mintBrandFor(address,address).notice: Mints a specific brand token for a given user. The brand is stated as its address.

mintFTFor(address,uint256,uint256,bytes).notice: Mints a specific fungible token type, in a certain amount.

mintNFTFor(address,uint256,bytes).notice: Mints a specific non-fungible token type, using a specific type (and always using an amount of 1). It is an error if the chosen type is unknown or < 2, since those types are reserved for being invalid or brands. Also, it is an error if the chosen type is not for that plug-in.

nftTypes(uint256).notice: Now, each NFT id will be registered here along its token type. The difference with the fungible tokens (they're already registered in the `tokenTypes` mapping) is that they need to be registered with a particular token type. Also, both the NFT id and its associated token type will be lower than (1<<255) since, otherwise, they would be using values corresponding to the FT side (both for IDs and type indices). Brand NFTs are not included in this mapping (they are only characterized by being < (1 << 160)).

onBrandOwnerChanged(address,address).notice: Hook to be invoked as part of a transfer from ERC1155.

plugins(address).notice: This is the list of plug-ins that are being added to the hub. Each contract has its separate logic but they have access to the same set of features. Once a contract is added, it will never be removed from this list. This mapping tells whether a contract in particular has permission(s) to define a type and mint tokens for an address.

pluginsCount().notice: This is the count of registered plug-ins.

pluginsList(uint256).notice: This is the enumerable list of plug-ins added to this hub.

setBrandRegistry(address).notice: Adds a plug-in contract to this metaverse.

setEconomy(address).notice: Set the economy contract to this metaverse.

setPermission(bytes32,address,bool).notice: Grants a permission to a user. This action is reserved to owners, approved operators, or allowed superusers. However, superuser cannot set, in particular, the SUPERUSER permission itself.

supportsInterface(bytes4).notice: A metaverse satisfies the IMetaverse and IERC165 interfaces.

tokenTypeResolvers(uint256).notice: Types are identified as integer values, and each registered type will have a non-zero responsible address (serving to metadata resolution and also to account for the existence of a given type). The type 1 (0x1) will be the first type, and actually it will be the brand type. Other NFT types will be registered using indices lower to (1<<255), while FT types will be registered using indices greater than or equal to that value (i.e. starting with binary {1}). In the case of the FTs, the index in this mapping is also their token id. This is not the same for NFTs (they have one extra level of indirection since multiple ids might share the same type). A special type id will be regarded as invalid type (i.e. it will not count as NFT nor FT type, but as a non-existent type): 0 (0x0). The responsible serves two purposes: The first one, is to resolve the metadata of a given token id (be it FT or NFT). The second one is to account for one of such tokens being burned. The responsible will actually be one of the registered plug-ins, on each case (save for the brands case, which is resolved by this contract, and the invalid case, which has no resolver).

tokenURI(uint256).notice: Retrieves the metadata uri of a given token. WARNING: This method will consume a lot of gas if invoked inside a transaction, so it is recommended to invoke this method in the context of a CALL, and never in the context of a SEND (even as part of other contract's code).

userdoc.notice: A metaverse hub can receive "plugs" (extensions) in the form of different contracts (implementing IMetaversePlugin). This plug mechanism allows extending the metaverse with new asset types and new asset instances (each plug-in is managed by the team, not publicly added by external users). Each of those contracts will make use of their own logic while interacting with the metaverse, which involves having full access to the whole metaverse assets (e.g. taking assets from the users or granting assets to the users).
